description: From Middle English doffen (“take off”), contraction of Old English dōn of. Equivalent to a blend of do +‎ off. Compare don, dup, dout, gauf.

verbs.description: doff (third-person singular simple present doffs, present participle doffing, simple past and past participle doffed)

entries.meaning: (clothing) To remove or take off (something such as clothing).
To remove or tip a hat, as in greeting, salutation or as a mark of respect.
examples: The rustics doffed their hats at the clergy.

entries.meaning: To get rid of, to throw off.
examples: Doff that stupid idea: it would never work.

entries.meaning: (reflexive) To strip; to divest; to undress.
examples: Heaven's King, who doffs himself weak flesh to wear.
